column1: The Afi Festival is an annual festival every August
column2: celebrated in commemoration of the city's patron saint
column3: San Jacinto de Polonia whose feast day falls on August 16. It came from the Ybanag word afi
column4: meaning fire.The concept of the "Afi" started in 2014
column5: renaming the former Pav-vurulun Festival. It reiterates and reaffirms the origins of the city's name. Stories say the place where the city center now stands was once “a wilderness that was cleared by fire” through kaingin (slash and burn farming). The main event of the celebration is its opening day
column6: where thousands of students convene for a field demonstration at night as torchbearers. In 2017
column7: 3500 students from Cagayan National High School and Cagayan State University - College of Human Kinetics danced with torches at the sports complex. The city is attempting to beat Indonesia's world record of 3

column9: where various elementary and secondary schools participate

column12: which flows to the Cagayan River
column13: a pansit festival featuring a pansit-eating contest
column16: among others.Before the additions and revisions to the native festival

column21: lively and extravagantly expressive." It was danced to the rhythm of the verso with the sincosinco accompaniment. Back then

column25: which serves as natural coloring.Pancit Batil Potun

column1: The Cagayan Museum and Historical Research Center houses an extensive collection of various artifacts and antiques of the province. In addition to animal fossils found in the valley

column4: known to locals as the San Jacinto Church which houses the city's patron saint. It is an elevated chapel built by Dominican friars in 1604 regarded as the oldest brick structure in the city. The St. Peter Metropolitan Cathedral is the biggest Spanish colonial church in Cagayan Valley which was construction from 1761 to 1767 under the supervision of Fr. Antonio Lobato
column5: OP. It is the seat of the Archdiocese of Tuguegarao. Both churches underwent reconstruction due to damages brought by World War II.

column1: Regional transport in Tuguegarao is vulnerable given its lack of distribution of arterial roads and inadequate traffic engineering planning and discipline.

The Buntun Highway-Luna Street network is a major four-lane road network of Tuguegarao that forms part of the National Route 51 (N51). It is the only road that serves west-side traffic to Tuguegarao. It links Tuguegarao to the western side of the Cagayan River via the Buntun Bridge
column2: further towns from the west side most notably the municipalities of Solana and Enrile
column3: the Philippine highway network and the Santiago-Tuguegarao Road.

column1: The Balzain Highway-Cagayan Valley Road is another major four-lane road network of Tuguegarao
column2: part of Cagayan Valley Road that comes through Balzain and Carig
column3: that forms part of the Asian Highway 26 (). It is the only road that serves north-bound traffic to Tuguegarao coming from the east side of the Cagayan River and most of Cagayan Valley. It also links Tuguegarao to surrounding municipalities
column4: most notably Iguig and Peñablanca. These two main arterial networks serves as the backbone for the majority of Tuguegarao's internal and inter-regional transportation.

column1: The Tuguegarao City West Diversion Road is an 8.99 km (6 mi) four-lane road under construction which starts from Barangay Carig traversing Barangays Linao

column4: aiming to decongest the Tuguegarao highway and provide alternative routes to nearby municipalities like Solana. The road project is divided into four phases expected to be completed by 2022.
